Speaker: 2nd draft
Dialogue: 6TH MARCH 2008

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Shelter.

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: I can't take in vagrants. Here's a penny. Now take it and go.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have no strength to go.

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: You can move off. And if there are others with you tell them we are not alone. We have a gentleman here, and dogs.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: But I must die if I am turned away.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: All of God's creatures must die. But not prematurely - and not on my doorstep I hope.

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: We've had a beggar woman come, Mr Rivers. I sent her - For shame!

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You did your duty in excluding her. Let me do mine in admitting her.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: St John, who is it?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I don't know; I found her at the door.

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: I thought her one of the gypsies from the cross.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She's as white as death.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Hannah, some water.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She's worn to nothing. She looks like a spectre. St John, if you hadn't taken her in, we would have fallen upon her dead body in the morning.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Mary.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: She's no vagrant; I'm sure of it.

Speaker: hannah
Dialogue: There's milk and bread for you.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Ask her her name.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I - I am J -

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: Jane Eyre!

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Please, tell us how we may help you.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Can we send for anyone? Who are your people?

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: Come out, rat. I know you are in here. Come out now and I won't punish you.

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: I have been looking for you these last ten minutes.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: Say forgive me, Master Reed.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have done nothing wrong. Master Reed.

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: Who gave you permission to read my book?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I wasn't aware it was yours.

Speaker: john reed
Dialogue: Everything in this house is mine. You're lucky to live here with gentleman's children like us. Your father had nothing. You should go and beg.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Wicked and cruel - you are a slaver - a murderer -

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I shall tell mother -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I hate you John Reed. I hate you -

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Mamma! Mamma! There's a rat! Rat!

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: For shame, hitting your master.

Speaker: miss abbot
Dialogue: If you don't sit still you must be tied down!

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: What we do is for your own good. If you are passionate and rude like this, your Aunt Reed will send you away.

Speaker: miss abbot
Dialogue: You're worse than us servants. We work for our keep; you do nothing. Pray for forgiveness Miss Eyre or something bad will come down that chimney and fetch you away.

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: Miss Eyre what is it?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Bessie!

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: Have you seen something?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: There was a light.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Bessie, I gave orders that she was to be left in the red room until I came.

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: But she screamed so loud ma'am.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: It is play-acting. Let her go. I know your tricks Jane Eyre and I abhor such artifice. Loose Bessie's hands, child.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No - Aunt, have pity -

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: And only when you are perfectly submissive will I let you out.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Please - I cannot bear it -

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Silence. This violence is repulsive.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I shall be killed -

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Get back!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Have mercy, have mercy I beg you -

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: She's awake.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I'm sure we'll find she's simply had a misunderstanding with her people. I hope she's not done anything deplorable; there's nothing so sad as a fallen young woman.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Look at the suffering in her eyes. They're like dark pools -

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: She has a peculiar face; I rather like it.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: She's not at all handsome.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: She's so ill, St John.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Ill or well, she'll always be plain.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: There is no sight so sad and so deplorable as that of a wicked little girl. Do you know, Jane Eyre, where the wicked go after death?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: They go to hell.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: And what is hell, can you tell me that?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: A pit full of fire.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: And should you like to fall into that pit and be burning there forever?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No sir.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: What must you do to avoid it?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I must keep in good health and not die.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: I've been her sole benefactress and her kindest friend. But she shows no gratitude and brings nothing but discord into my house.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: What is her parentage?

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: She's an orphan. Her mother was my late husband's sister. On his deathbed he exhorted me to care for her. I have always treated her as one of my own.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: All liars will have their portion in the lake burning with fire and brimstone. She shall be watched, Mrs Reed.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: I wish her to be made useful, to be kept humble.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: You can rest assured dear lady that we mortify our girls in the sentiments of vanity and pride. They are taught to be quiet, plain and modest.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: And as for its vacations, it must spend them all at Lowood.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: So, Rat, you're being sent away. It's as I thought; you're not fit to associate with me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You are not fit to associate with me!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You said I was a liar. Well I am not. If I was, I should say that I loved you and I don't. I dislike you the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed. He is a liar, not I.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: How dare you speak in this manner.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'll never call you Aunt again as long as I live and if anyone asks how I liked you I'll say that the very thought of you makes me sick.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: You wouldn't dare.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'll remember how you thrust me back into the Red Room and locked me there to my dying day. Even when you knew it was haunted and I begged to be let out. People think you are good but you are bad and hard-hearted and I'll let everyone at Lowood know what you have done!

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Children must be corrected for their faults.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Deceit is not my fault!

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: But you are passionate.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: My Uncle Reed is in heaven and can see all that you do and think; so can my mother and father. They know how you hate me and wish me dead. They can see. They see everything you do and they will judge you, Mrs Reed.

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: You're such a queer, solitary little thing. If only you could make yourself more appealing. Perhaps if you tried smiling from time to time, people would find you more pleasant -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Don't scold me Bessie. I know you dislike me -

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: I don't dislike you Miss; I'm fonder of you than of anyone.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You don't show it.

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: Miss Jane -

Speaker: miss temple
Dialogue: What's your name, child?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Jane Eyre.

Speaker: miss temple
Dialogue: You are very young to be sent alone, Jane Eyre.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: My name is Jane Elliott...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Jane Elliot.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Where do you come from, Miss Elliott?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Who can we send for to help you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No one.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Do you mean to say that you are absolutely without home and without friends?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: How did you come to be roaming the moors, Miss Elliott?

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Don't upset her, St John. She must not be interrogated so.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rivers, you and you sisters have done me a great service, the greatest man can do - you have rescued me from death.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: How are we to help you if we know nothing about you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'll tell you as much as I can. I am an orphan; brought up a dependent; educated in a charity school where I passed six years as a pupil and two as a teacher. I left a year since to become a private governess -

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: YES -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: A good situation, where I remained until...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Diana, didn't I say so? Didn't I say she was a governess?

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: We did wonder. We mean no offence but you have a certain look. Mary and I work as governesses too.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We are currently trying to teach ourselves German, so we may find better positions.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You're not working at present?

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: We came home only for our father's funeral.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He died three weeks ago.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am very sorry to hear it.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why did you leave your place of employment?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I... It was a catastrophe.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: What did you do?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am free from any blame, sir. I was happy.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: That's enough for now, St John.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You must rest, Miss Elliott.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why did you start?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because that is not my name.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: You haven't given us your real name?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because I must not ever be found.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Join me to thyself with an inseparable band of love... For thou, even thou alone, dost satisfy him that loveth thee...

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Welcome to our table, Miss Elliott.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'd appreciate it if you called me Jane. It is my own name.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's wonderful to see you on your feet, Miss Jane.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I trust I will not be eating long at your expense, Mr Rivers.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You wish to be independent of my charity?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I wish to work, sir. Show me how to work or how to seek work; that's all I ask.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: You're not fit enough to work.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: My sisters have always taken pleasure in keeping injured birds but I'm more inclined to put you in a way of keeping yourself - and shall endeavour to do so, if that's what you wish.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: With all my heart, sir.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: It's a shame she has no choice of helpers, St John, and must put up with such crusty people as you.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: This school you were at, Miss Elliot, this charitable institution; what did it prepare you for?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Most thorough.

Speaker: miss scatcherd
Dialogue: Burns, Helen Burns!

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: I might have known. The new girl. Step forward, Jane Eyre.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Come now, don't cry.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You're not allowed to speak to me. I must be shunned.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Mr Brocklehurst is not a God. He's not liked or admired here -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: He said I was a liar.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: JANE -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am not a liar!

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: If your own conscience approves you, then so will I.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How do you bear it?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Bear what?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Being struck.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm a trial to Miss Scatcherd. She hits me to improve me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: If she hit me I would get that birch from her hand and break it under her nose.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You'd just be punished even more. It's part of life here.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have always been excluded and alone and hated. Miss Abbott used to call me an ugly little toad.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're not ugly. Do you know what is inside you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: The spark of your spirit, the principle of light and thought, pure and bright, as perfect as anything created.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Your soul. Your soul is beautiful, your soul has value - more value than anything on earth.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Is that true?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Yes. God sees your beauty. Even as you stand on that stool, there is an invisible world around you, a kingdom of spirits. It is everywhere. Angels see your pain. Angels know your innocence.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Angels?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Do you not believe in angels?

Speaker: miss temple
Dialogue: Come here, Girls.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We've lived here all our lives but the house must be shut up now.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We can't afford to keep it on. Diana and I will return to our charges in a few days and St John will go to his parsonage.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: It'll be a hard parting for us. We may not see him again for years.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why ever not?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He means to be a missionary. He's going to India to do Gods's work.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Can he not do God's work here?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: This quiet parish will never do for him; he almost raves in his restlessness. It breaks our hearts.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: St John burns with talents and ambition. But he lacks the means for advancement here. Our poverty thwarts him at every turn and so he has chosen to lay all his gifts on God's altar.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We've tried to persuade him to stay but in some things our brother is - he is -

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: Inexorable as death.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We are now without father. We'll soon be without home and brother.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: In one thing you are fortunate.

Speaker: miss temple
Dialogue: This is the result of semi- starvation and neglected colds; Brockelhurst's idea of mortifying their bodies to save their souls. TYPHUS -

Speaker: madame pierrot
Dialogue: Write to the governors. You must.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Helen.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Is it you, Jane? Have you come to say goodbye?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You're cold.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I'm very happy. I am going home.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Back to your father?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: My father has a new wife. He'll not miss me much.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then where?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: To my future home, where all is light. I am going to God.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Don't be sad. I will escape great suffering by dying young.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I don't have any talent to make my way in life. I should be always at fault. But God is my friend. He loves me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then he must save you.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He is saving me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I won't leave you.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You're so warm and alive. Jane, you have a passion for living.

Speaker: miss temple
Dialogue: Jane...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No, no, no -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Have you something for me to do?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You are doing something already. May I see?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: That's Miss Temple on her wedding day. She was my teacher; a great influence on me. Under her guidance I became a teacher too.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: St John -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No, Mary, please -

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: See how skilled Jane is.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: How fierce I am, Miss Elliott.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rivers, I wondered if you had yet heard of any work that I could do.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I found you a situation some days ago but I've delayed telling you because the work is lowly and I fear you'll scorn it.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I shan't mind what I do.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: As I am poor and obscure, the help I can offer is of the meanest sort.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: St John, what are you going to offer her? Not washerwoman, I hope?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: When I took over the parish two years ago it had no school. I opened one for boys; I now intend to open one for girls. The school mistress will have a two-roomed cottage paid for by local benefactors and she will receive fifteen pounds a year. You can see how humble, how ignoble it is.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rivers, I thank you heartily and I accept with all my heart.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: But you comprehend me? It's a village school - cottagers daughters. What will you do with all your fine accomplishments?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I will save them until they are wanted. They will keep.

Speaker: brocklehurst
Dialogue: I hear you are to leave us, Miss Eyre.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes. Excuse me.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: How do you do, my dear? What a long and tedious journey you must have had of it. John is quite the slowest driver in the county. You must be cold to the bone.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Are you Mrs Fairfax?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Indeed I am; come and warm yourself in here.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Draw nearer the fire. John is taking your trunk up to your room.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Am I to have the pleasure of meeting Miss Fairfax tonight?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Miss Fairfax - my pupil?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Oh you mean Miss Varens; Mr Rochester's ward. She is to be your pupil.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Who is Mr Rochester?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Why, the owner of Thornfield.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I thought Thornfield Hall belonged to you.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Oh bless you child, what an idea. To me? I am only the housekeeper.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Forgive me -

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: There is a distant connection between Mr Rochester and I - his mother was a Fairfax - but I'd never presume on it. Heavens, me, owner of Thornfield?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: We shall have a cheerful house this winter...

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: I'm sure that last winter - and what a severe one - if it didn't rain it snowed and if it didn't snow it blew a gale - last winter I declare that not a soul came to the house from November to February.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: OH -

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Good night, my dear. I hope you'll be comfy.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What a beautiful house.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Mr Rochester's visits here are always unexpected. He doesn't like to arrive and find everything all swathed up, so I keep it in constant readiness. Now, come and meet Miss Varens. Did I mention she was French?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Sophie has been crying because no one understands. Nobody can speak to us except for Mr Rochester and he has gone away.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Would you ask her about her parents? Mr Rochester's neglected to tell me anything about her.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Where did you live Adele, before you came to Thornfield?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: With Maman - but she is gone to the Holy Virgin now.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Her mother has passed away.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Maman used to teach me to dance and say verses. When gentlemen came to see her I used to dance for them or sit on their knees and sing. May I sing for you now?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Adele is going to show us her accomplishments.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: How very French...

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Me! It is me!

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Here. For you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: No one. This part of the house is quite empty, except for you and me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I heard someone.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: You can't have done.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: A laugh. Someone laughed.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Oh - that must be Grace Poole. She likes to sit up here with her sewing. Rather an eccentric soul.  Grace? Grace!

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: I thought I might find you up here. I've been waiting to pour our tea.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm not in need of tea, thank you.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: What is it, child? You've been here three months now and I'm worried that the position is not enough / to occupy your -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh, Mrs Fairfax, no. I'm so thankful to be at Thornfield. Please don't think I'm so ungrateful as to be discontented.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: But it's a quiet life, isn't it? This isolated house; a still doom for a young woman...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I wish a woman could have action in her life, like a man. It agitates me to pain that the sky- line over there is ever our limit. I long sometimes for a power of vision that would overpass it. If I could behold all I imagine... I've never seen a city, never spoken with men. I've never even seen a town of any size. And I fear my whole life will pass, without ever having...

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Well now - exercise is a great cure for anything, they say.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What the deuce -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Can I do anything, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Get back.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Are you injured, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Where do you come from?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thornfield Hall.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Whose house is that?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rochester's.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Do you know Mr Rochester?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No, I've never seen him.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're not a servant there...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am the governess, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: The governess.  Deuce take me, I had forgotten.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Then try to get hold of his bridle and lead him to me.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Mr Rochester is here.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Go and change your frock; he wishes to meet you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have to change?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Oh yes - I always dress for the evening when Mr Rochester is here.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: But all my dresses are the same.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: You must have one that is better? He's in a terrible humour; the doctor has been. His horse fell in Hay lane and his ankle is sprained.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Here is Miss Eyre, Sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Let her sit.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You've been resident here three months?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And from whence do you hail; what's your tale of woe?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Pardon?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: All governesses have a tale of woe; what's yours?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I was brought up by my Aunt, Mrs Reed of Gateshead, in a house far finer than this. At ten years old I went to Lowood school where I received as good an education as I could hope for. I have no tale of woe, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Where are your parents?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Dead.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Do you remember them?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And why are you not with Mrs Reed of Gateshead now?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: She cast me off, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because I was burdensome and she disliked me.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Lowood; that's a charity school, isn't it?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: How long did you survive there?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Eight years.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: No tale of woe...

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: I daily thank providence for sending us Miss Eyre. She's a kind and patient teacher and an invaluable / companion -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Don't trouble yourself to give her a character. I'll judge for myself. She began by felling my horse.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I have her to thank for this sprain.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Where did you get your copies?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Out of my head.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: That head I now see on your shoulders?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Who's this?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: The evening star.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Why did you bewitch my horse?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Tonight I will have my cadeaux. He always bring me a cadeaux.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Sorry to disturb. He's asked for your art.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: He wishes to have it.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: To show to his company, I should think. Is this it here? Thank you.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Monsieur!

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Ah, there she is...

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Ma boite, ma boite!

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Take it away you genuine daughter of Paris and amuse yourself with disembowelling it.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: We'll open it together, shall we?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Miss Eyre. Sit there.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Oh Ciel! Que c'est beau!

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Nor do I particularly enjoy simple-minded old ladies. But you might suit me - if you would.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: By distracting me from the mire of my thoughts.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte...

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Precisely.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Let's try it on, shall we?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And that is how she charmed my English gold out of my English breeches pocket.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What fault do you find with me? I have all my limbs and all my FEATURES -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rochester, it was a blunder. I ought to have replied that beauty is of little consequence -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Now you stick a knife under my EAR -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You have other qualities, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Just so; other qualities... When I was your age I was a felling enough fellow. I might have been insulted then. You're blushing Miss Eyre.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And though you're not pretty any more than I am handsome, I must say it becomes you.  And now I see you're fascinated by the flowers on the rug.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What about, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: The choice of subject is entirely yours.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How can I introduce a subject when I don't know what'll interest you?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: The fact is, Miss Eyre, I don't wish to treat you like an inferior.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yet you'd command me to speak?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Well I probably have a right to be a little abrupt and exacting on the grounds of my superiority in age. There must be twenty years between us and a century's advance in experience.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I don't think you have a right to command me just because you're older. Your claim to superiority depends on the use you've made of your time and experience.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I've made indifferent use of both. And this is why I sit, galled by my own thoughts - and order you to divert me. Are you very hurt by my tone of command?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: There are few masters who'd trouble to enquire whether their paid subordinates were hurt by their commands.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Oh yes... paid subordinate; I'd forgotten the salary. Well on that mercenary ground, will you consent to speak with me as my equal - without thinking that the request arises from insolence?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'd never mistake informality for insolence, sir. One, I rather like. The other, nothing free born should ever submit to - even for a salary.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Humbug. Most free-born things would submit to anything for a salary. But I mentally shake hands with you for your answer.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You've clearly not spent much time in the company of schoolgirl governesses. I'm the same plain kind of bird as all the rest, with my couple of accomplishments and my common tale of woe.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I envy you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Your openness, your clear conscience, your unpolluted mind. If I were eighteen I think we truly would be equals. Nature meant me to be a good man, one of the better kind and as you see, I am not so.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Are you a villain then, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'm a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the dissipations that the rich and worthless try to put on life.  When I was your age, fate dealt me a blow. I was - cursed with a burden to carry through life. I lacked the wisdom to remain cool and I turned desperate. Dread remorse, Miss Eyre. It is the poison of life.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then you'll degenerate still more.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Are you preaching to me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm reminding you of your own words; remorse is the poison of life.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: But, Miss Eyre, if the pleasure I was seeking was sweet and fresh; if it was an inspiration; if it wore the robes of an angel of light... what then?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I don't know. To speak truth, I don't understand you at all.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: My heart has long been a charnel house. Perhaps it'll transform into a shrine.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Sir, I find the conversation has got out of my depth.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're afraid of me because I talk like a sphynx.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm not afraid.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Yes you are.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I've simply no wish to talk nonsense.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: If you did it would be in such a grave, quiet manner that I would mistake it for sense. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Just as it turns to come down - that's when you hit it.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Because I start to win!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Have mercy, Adele. Play with Pilot for a while.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: On the contrary. I like your game. I like this cold, hard day. I like Thornfield.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Mademoiselle - Il faut jouer -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Get back! Keep at a distance child, or go in!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: To fall in love, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You've never felt love, have you Miss Eyre? Your soul still sleeps.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Does it?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're still floating gently in the stream of life, unaware of the rocks ahead waiting to dash you to pieces.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Were you dashed to pieces, Mr Rochester?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Not by Celine. How can one ever truly love a woman one has paid for?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: But you took her on?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Some years later, I heard that Celine had abandoned the brat, disappeared to Italy and left it destitute. So I lifted it from the mud and slime of Paris and brought it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. My one good work in a sea of countless sins.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It is I, Jane Eyre, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What in the name of all the elves in Christendom have you done with me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: For heaven's sake get up. Somebody has plotted something; you must find out who. I'll light the lamp -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Light the lamp at your peril.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I heard a laugh outside my door loud enough to wake me. I opened it. Someone was running towards the third floor.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What the deuce can she do?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then I'll wake John and Martha.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Not at all. Stay here. You're shivering.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Did you see anything when you opened your chamber door?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Only the candle on the ground.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: But you heard a laugh?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Have you heard that laugh before?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: There's a woman who sews here; Grace Poole - She laughs in that way, I think.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Just so. Grace Poole - you have guessed it. Well, you're no talking fool; please say nothing about this.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: BUT -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I will account for this state of affairs. Go back to your room and say nothing.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  Good-night.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Is that how you're going to leave me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You said I should go.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, fire is a horrible death. You have saved my life. Don't walk past me as if we were strangers.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What am I to do then, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: At least... shake hands.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: There is no debt.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I knew you would do me good in some way. I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you. Their expression did not - did not strike delight into my very inmost being so, for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies... You.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Good night then, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: So you will leave me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm cold.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: Good day to you, miss.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What's happened here?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I did. I heard a strange laugh.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: It's hardly likely the master would laugh when he was in such danger. Perhaps you were dreaming.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I was not.

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: Then you didn't think of opening your door and looking out?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Has Mr Rochester not sent for us today?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Why, he's gone away. Were you not aware? He left after breakfast.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: I saw her two years ago when Mr Rochester had a party here. Oh, she was a beauty; I daresay the most elegant girl I've ever seen. So tall, with raven hair cascading down her back; I don't know how she'd had it done. She sang a duet with Mr Rochester. They made a lovely harmony.

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Qu'avez vous mademoiselle?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Nothing. Speak in English, please.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you, girls. You may go.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Do you find the work too hard?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Not at all. I'm getting on very well.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Do you feel the solitude an oppression?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I hardly have time to notice it.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Then perhaps your accommodations have disappointed you. They are in truth scanty enough -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: A few months ago I had nothing. I was wretched. Now I have a home and work; free and honest. I wonder at the goodness of God and at the generosity of my friends.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: What you had left before I met you, I don't know. But I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation to look back.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It's what I mean to do.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: We can overcome every kind of human weakness. A year ago I was myself intensely miserable. I considered my life was so wretched that it must be changed - or I would die. After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke. I heard my call from God. Put your trust in him, Jane. Let him lead you to your future.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: A year ago, I was weak enough to fall in love.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You could have been happy.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: A slave in a fool's paradise? I'd rather my life had purpose -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Nothing in the world.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: He's back in three days he says - heavens that's Thursday - and not alone. He gives directions to prepare all the best rooms. I'm to get more staff from the George Inn. The ladies will bring their maids, the gentlemen, valets. We must accommodate them all. Supplies to be got; linen, the MATTRESSES -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: May I assist you, Mrs Fairfax?

Speaker: under cook
Dialogue: She gets good wages, I'd guess?

Speaker: leah
Dialogue: Wish I had as good; not one fifth what Mrs Poole receives.

Speaker: under cook
Dialogue: She's a good hand, I daresay.

Speaker: leah
Dialogue: Not everyone could do it, that's for sure, not even for the money.

Speaker: under cook
Dialogue: No wonder the master relies on HER -

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: They're here! They're here!

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Excuse me, miss.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Good evening.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What is it, darling?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: She sing like Maman.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Tonight. He wants you both in the drawing room after dinner.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Not me, surely.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: It's his particular wish.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: He was being polite.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: I'm instructed to tell you that if you resist, he'll come up and get you himself. You needn't stay long. Just let him see you and then slip away. Don't worry; no one'll look at you.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: May I present Miss Adele Varens?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Bon jour, mesdames, monsieurs.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Why, what a little puppet.

Speaker: lady ingram
Dialogue: Is this your ward, Mr Rochester?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: louisa eshton
Dialogue: What a love of a child.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I thought you weren't fond of children?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're right; I'm not.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Then what induced you to take charge of that little doll?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: She was left on my hands.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Why don't you send her to school?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: She has a governess.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: You should hear mamma on the chapter of governesses. I had half a dozen in my day - all detestable, ridiculous incubi - were they not, mamma?

Speaker: lady ingram
Dialogue: Did you speak, my lily flower?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I said governesses.

Speaker: lady ingram
Dialogue: Oh, don't mention them; the very word makes me nervous! I've suffered a martyrdom from their incompetence and caprice. I thank heaven we're now done with them.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; nuisance.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Donna Bianca, I give you beauty.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Beauty? Why there's nothing new to be said. I give you back male beauty. Mamma, what's your idea of male beauty?

Speaker: lady ingram
Dialogue: My son, of course.

Speaker: lord ingram
Dialogue: Hear hear.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, Tedo's quite typical of the young men of today. They're so absorbed in the pursuit of fashion that they've forgotten how to be men at all.

Speaker: lord ingram
Dialogue: I say -

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: A woman who neglects herself is a blot on humanity. But a man should pay no heed to his looks.  A man should possess only strength and valour. He could be a gentleman or a highwayman. His beauty lies in his power.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: So a Levantine pirate would do for you?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: As long as he resembled you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Why did you leave the room?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am tired, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Why didn't you come and speak to me? I haven't seen you for weeks. It would have been normal and polite to wish me good evening.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You seemed engaged, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What have you been doing while I've been gone?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Teaching Adele.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You look pale.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am well.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're depressed; your eyes are shining with tears. What's the meaning of this?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: A gentleman has arrived to see you, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: He says he's travelled a long way, from Spanish Town, Jamaica -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Spanish Town...

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Mr Richard Mason. He says you're old friends. I've put him in the morning room.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Not at all. Please tell him I'll see him directly.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Can I help you sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, if all those people came and spat at me, what would you do?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Turn them out of the room sir, if I could.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And if they cast you out for adhering to me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I should care nothing about it.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You'd dare censure for my sake?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: For the sake of any friend who deserved it.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Fairfax...

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Richard. How the devil are you?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: He is yours.

Speaker: lady ingram
Dialogue: Oh what is it?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Who is hurt?

Speaker: lord ingram
Dialogue: Where the devil is Rochester?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'm here, be composed.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: What awful event has taken place?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: A servant has had a nightmare, that's all. She's an excitable, nervous person and has taken a fit with fright.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Is there anything I might do?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Miss Ingram, ladies, please return to your nests like the doves that you are. You'll take cold for certain if you stay in this icy gallery any longer.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Be steady. I need you.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Am I dying?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: She bit me - while the knife was in - Bit me -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It was folly to attempt the interview tonight and alone.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: I thought I might have done some good.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It makes me impatient to hear you.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: She sucked the blood. Said she'd drain me - like a vampire -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Think of her as dead, dead and buried. Say nothing!

Speaker: dr carter
Dialogue: I only wish I could have got here sooner. He'd not have bled so much.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, make sure the way is clear.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'll ride over tomorrow to see how you do. Goodbye, Richard.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Fairfax - Let her treated as tenderly as may be -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I do my best and have done it and will do it!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It is slime and cobwebs.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Will Grace Poole stay here now?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Oh yes, don't trouble your head about her.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: But sir -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Grace Poole is not the danger.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Keep vigil with me again, the night before I marry. For now you've met my lovely one and you know her. She's a rare one, isn't she?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: A strapper, a real strapper; big and buxom...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'd do anything for you sir, anything that was right.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And if I ever bid you do what was wrong, you'd turn to me, quiet and pale and say 'I cannot do it.' And you'd be as immutable as a fixed star.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: That's for the look you had on your face.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Does that creeping creature want you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: If you please, I want leave of absence for a week or two.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What to do?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: This is from my old nurse, Bessie. She says my cousin John Reed is dead. He ruined himself and has committed suicide. The news has so shocked his mother, my Aunt, that it's brought on a stroke.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What good can you do her?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: She's been asking for me. I parted from her very badly and I can't neglect her wishes now.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Promise me you won't stay long.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Sir, it seems you are soon to be married.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What of it?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Adele should go to school.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: To get her out of my bride's way who might otherwise trample her?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: And I must seek another situation. I intend to advertise.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: At your peril you advertise. Trust it to me. I'll find you a good situation in time.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: And sir? Forgive me but I have had no wages as yet.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: How much do I owe you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Fifteen pounds.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Here's fifty.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: That's too much.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Take your wages.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I cannot.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Then I only have a ten.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Now you owe me five.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Just so. Come back for it quickly. Meantime, I shall safeguard it in here.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Not a whit, sir. You are not to be trusted at all.

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: Bless you! - I knew you'd come.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Bessie... I'm not too late? How is Mrs Reed?

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: She may linger yet a while. She's spoken of you daily. At first we couldn't tell what she was saying but when her speech came clear we heard 'Jane Eyre, get Jane Eyre.'

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Shall I see her now?

Speaker: bessie
Dialogue: I'll take you up directly. But look at you. What a lady you've become. Why you're almost pretty.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Aunt Reed? It is Jane Eyre. You sent for me, and here I am.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: No one knows the trouble I have with that child. Such a burden. Left on my hands. Speaking to me like a fiend. The fever at Lowood. She should have died!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why do you hate her so?

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Her mother. Reed's sister - his beloved. When news came of her death he wept like a fool. Sent for the baby. Sickly thing - not strong like mine. But Reed loved it. Kept it by his bed. Made me vow to bring the creature up. Why did he not love mine?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am Jane Eyre, Aunt.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: You. Is there no one in the room?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: We are alone.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: I've twice done you wrong. I broke the vow I made to Reed -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Please, don't think of it -

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: I am dying; I must get it out!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: 'Madam, will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre. I desire her to come to me at Madeira. Fortune has blessed my endeavours and as I am childless I wish to adopt her and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave. Yours, John Eyre, Madeira.'

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: Because I wrote and told him you had died of typhus at Lowood school. You fury. You were born to be my torment. I'll never forget how you turned on me and raged.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Forgive me.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: You cursed me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I would have loved you if you'd let me.

Speaker: mrs reed
Dialogue: My life has been cursed.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Please, let us be reconciled.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: My mother.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have been with my aunt sir, who is dead.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: A true Janian reply. If I dared I'd touch you, to see if you were real...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you Mr Rochester. I'm strangely glad to get back again to you. Wherever you are is my home.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: We're expecting the announcement very soon. He went down to London only last week to buy her a new carriage.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then we must accept it. He'll soon bring home his bride.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Come and look at this fellow, Jane.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'll be sad to leave it.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Yes, but it can't be helped. I soon hope to be a bridegroom.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Have you found me a new situation, sir?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: A situation, yes of course. It's the least I can do for a faithful paid subordinate such as yourself. You're to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs Dionysus O'Gall of Bitternut Lodge, Connaught.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Connaught?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You'll like Ireland. They're such warm-hearted people, they say.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It is a long way away, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: From what?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: From here. From you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: We've been good friends, Jane haven't we? But with the Irish sea between us you'd soon forget me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I wish I could. I wish I'd never come here. I love Thornfield - I've lived a full life here. I've not been trampled on or petrified or buried with inferior minds. I've talked face to face with what I reverence, with what I delight in. I've known you Mr Rochester -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Then why must you be torn from me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because of your bride.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I have no bride.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: But you will have.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Yes, I will.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then I must go.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You must stay.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Do you think I could stay to become nothing to you? Am I an automaton, a machine without feelings?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: JANE -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have as much soul as you and full as much heart. I'm not speaking to you through mortal flesh. It's my spirit that addresses your spirit as if we'd passed through the grave and stood at God's feet, equal - as we are.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: As we are.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Let me go.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: NO -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Then let your will decide your destiny. I offer you my hand, my heart and a share of all this.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Are you mocking me?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Do you doubt me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Entirely.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You have no faith in me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Not a whit.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You little sceptic.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Your bride is Miss Ingram -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What love have I for Miss Ingram? What love has she for me? I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was lost and got instant coldness. I wanted to make you jealous, to move you to love me. It's you - you strange, unearthly thing. I love you as my own flesh. You - poor and obscure as you are - please accept me as your husband.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Are you in earnest?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I must have you for my own.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You wish me to be your wife?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I swear it.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You love me.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then sir, I will marry you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It will atone. It will atone.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I must go.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Good night. Good night.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Have you accepted him?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Well I never would have thought.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Am I a monster? Is it so impossible that Mr Rochester should love me?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: No, I've long noticed that you were a sort of pet of his. But you're so young and so little acquainted with men. I don't want to grieve you child, but let me put you on your guard. Gentlemen in his position... Let's just say they're not accustomed to marry their governesses. Until you are wed, distrust yourself as well as him. Please, keep him at a distance -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Is this my pale elf? This sunny faced girl with the radiant eyes?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It is I, Jane Eyre sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Soon to be Jane Rochester.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It can never be, sir. Human beings were not meant to enjoy complete happiness on this earth. It's too much like a fairy tale.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Let the fairy tale begin.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send certain jewels. In a day or two I hope to pour them into you lap -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh, no sir -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I will put the diamond chain around your neck myself -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I don't want jewels -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'll dress you in these satins -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Then you won't know me. I'll not be Jane Eyre any longer but an ape in a harlequin's jacket. Put them away.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Well for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven't your equal.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm naturally proud. And hard and flinty. You ought to know what sort of bargain you've made while you've still got time to rescind it. I want only one thing from you, Mr Rochester.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And what's that?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Your regard.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It's your time now, little tyrant but it'll soon be mine and when I have seized you, to have and to hold, I'll attach you to a chain, like this...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Adele?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm afraid.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, this is the only explanation. It must have been half-dream, half- reality. A woman did enter your room last night and that woman was - must have been - Grace Poole -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It was not Grace Poole.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You know how strange she is. What did she do to me? To Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I was not asleep.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You noticed her entrance and her actions but you've ascribed to her an appearance different from her own. That was your nightmare -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I know what I saw.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I see you'd ask why I keep such a woman in my house. When we've been married a year and a day, I promise I'll tell you. Are you satisfied Jane? Do you accept my solution?

Speaker: adele
Dialogue: Mademoiselle...

Speaker: sophie
Dialogue: Please, you must look.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Come.

Speaker: wood
Dialogue: I require and charge you both, as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgement when the secrets of all hearts shall be revealed, that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not be lawfully joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it.

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: The marriage cannot go on. I declare the existence of an impediment.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: The ceremony is quite broken off. An insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: Mr Rochester has a wife now living.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Where is your proof?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: That does not prove that my wife is still living.

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: She was living two months ago.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: I have a witness to the fact.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Produce him or go to hell.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Good God -

Speaker: wood
Dialogue: Sir, you are in a sacred place -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: What have you to say?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: She is at Thornfield Hall. I saw her there in April. I'm her brother.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: This girl knew nothing. She thought all was fair and legal. She never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Get back! Do not come near! Go, all of you - keep your congratulations - they come fifteen years too late!

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: Sir, you can't be bringing folk in here. It's madness.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: This clothed hyena is my wife.

Speaker: wood
Dialogue: Let us go. We have seen enough.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: My own demon, Bertha.

Speaker: briggs
Dialogue: You, madam, are clearly not to blame. Your uncle will be glad to hear it.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: JANE -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I cannot.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I deserve a hail of fire.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm tired and sick. I need some water.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: How are you now?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Much better, sir. I shall be well again soon.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I know you. You are thinking. Talking is no use; you are thinking how to act.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: All is changed, sir. I must change too.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Yes. There is no doubt that we both must change. I was wrong ever to keep you here; this narrow stone vault with its one real fiend. I'll shut it up. I'll pay Mrs Poole two hundred a year to care for its inmate and then no one will be harmed when she is prompted to burn people, to stab them, to bite the flesh from their bones -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Sir - you speak of her with hate - it is cruel. She cannot help being mad.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It's not because she's mad that I hate her. If you were mad do you think that I'd hate you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Then you know nothing about me, nothing about the way I love. Your mind is my treasure - and if it were broken it would be my treasure still. You are my sympathy, my better self, my angel. I will wrap my whole existence round you. Let us leave here tomorrow. Come with me - as my wife.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'll pledge you my fidelity -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You can't.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You'll live a happy, most innocent life -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I must leave you, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Don't you love me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I do love you - But I mustn't show it or speak it ever again. I must begin a new existence - strange scenes among strange faces. I must part from you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Must be a part of me; that's what you mean. You are my wife, Jane. In truth -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You have a wife already.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I was tricked, duped into wedlock with that demon-hate, that harlot, that succubus upstairs. My father wanted her money and so I was sent to Spanish Town and the match was made. I hardly spoke with her. I was dazzled, ignorant, raw. My senses were besotted and I married her - gross, grovelling mole-eyed blockhead that I was.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I earnestly pity you, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, it's not pity that I see in your face. It's not pity -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Do not say it -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: It is love.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: STOP -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I was wrong to deceive you. It was cowardly. I should have appealed to your spirit - as I do now - should have opened my life, described my hunger for a better existence - shown you my chains. I give you my life. I give you my pledge. Please, be my wife.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I can not.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You would be my equal.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I would make it so.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You once told me that hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Not my mistress -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I would not degrade you by having you live with a slave.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I said wife, my wife -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: And now?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I would.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane, it would not be wicked to love me...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: It would be to obey you. I care for myself.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Will you listen to me?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I must listen to myself -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Will you hear reason?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Let me go -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Because if you won't I'll try violence.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: God help me!

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You have never called me by my name. My name is Edward.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Edward.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr St John - What on earth brings you away from your hearth on a night like this? Has anything happened? There's no bad news I hope?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: How easily alarmed you are.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You are recklessly rash about your own health.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Nonsense.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why are you come?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: An inhospitable question.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I mean on a night like this -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms. Besides I've been told half a story and I'm most impatient to find out the end.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Please...

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Twenty years ago, a poor curate fell in love with a rich man's daughter and married her. She was disowned by her family and two years later the rash pair were both dead. They left a daughter which charity received into her lap - as cold as that snow drift I almost stuck fast in. Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations. It was reared by an aunt-in-law; I come to names now - Mrs Reed of Gateshead.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rivers! -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I can guess your feelings but hear me to the end. Of Mr Rochester's character I know nothing but he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl and at the very altar she discovered that he had a wife yet alive. His subsequent conduct is a matter of pure conjecture but when the governess was enquired after it was discovered that she had fled Thornfield Hall and no trace of her has since been found. Now isn't that an odd tale?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Since you know so much, perhaps you can tell me how he is.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mr Rochester; how is he?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I'm ignorant of all concerning him.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: The solicitor - Mr Briggs - does he have any news of Mr Rochester?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Are you not going to enquire why he has gone to such lengths to find you?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What does he want with me?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr John Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property and that you are now rich.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You are rich; quite an heiress.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How much am I worth?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Oh a trifle. Twenty thousand pounds - but what of that?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Twenty thousand pounds?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: If you'd committed a murder and I'd found you out, you could scarcely look more aghast.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: There must be some mistake. It's two thousand, surely.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: It's twenty. You look desperately miserable about it, I must say.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why did Mr Briggs write to you?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You see, that is the strange thing. It makes me wonder what power or providence led you to our door. Your name is Jane Eyre.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Then I'm you namesake. I was christened St John Eyre Rivers.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: St John Eyre -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: My mother had two brothers, one was a clergyman, your father, the other was John Eyre of Madeira. Mr Briggs wrote to inform us that the clergyman's daughter was lost. I have been able to find her out; that is all.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Your mother was my father's sister?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: My uncle John was your uncle John?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: That is correct.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: So you, Diana and Mary -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: We are cousins, yes.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh, I am glad! - I am glad!

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Here you are neglecting essential points to pursue trifles. You were utterly downhearted when I told you that you were rich and now, for a matter of no moment, you are deliriously happy.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Of no moment? You have sisters and maybe don't care for a cousin but I have nobody. I have been alone, always. And now three relations are born into my world full grown. Oh, I am glad. You, who saved my life -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You must try to tranquillise your feelings.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Write to Diana and Mary. Tell them to hand in notice and come home. They will have five thousand each and so will you.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I've told you the news too quickly. You're confused.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Don't put me out of patience, cousin. I am rational enough. Twenty thousand divided equally between the nieces and nephews of our uncle, gives five to each.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: This is acting on first impulse. You don't know what it is to have WEALTH -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: And you cannot imagine - family - I never had a home. I never had brothers and sisters -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Jane, I will be your brother.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: diana
Dialogue: You call Jane your sister but you don't treat her as such. You should kiss her too.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Di, you are very provoking.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Good night.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You are wasted here.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Am I not being useful?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You should look beyond Moor House, beyond the selfish calm and comfort of affluence.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Beyond to what?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I go to India in six weeks.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: So soon? -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I can see what your gifts are and why they were given. Come with me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm not fit for it. I have no vocation.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: You're far too humble.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: St John have mercy. I feel my mind shrinking -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Don't be afraid. You are diligent, faithful, docile, courageous, gentle and heroic. Cease to mistrust yourself. I trust you unreservedly. Let me give you time to think. But know this; in you, I recognise a fellow soul, a soul that would revel in the flame and excitement of sacrifice.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I used to long for a life of action, to overleap the horizon, to move in the world of men. Maybe God is giving me this. And what is there for me here? Pain and longing for what can't be. I don't know how long I would survive in India. My frame isn't strong. But I'll go with you, if I may go free.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Free?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You and I had better not marry.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because I am your sister.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: But you'll go with me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Conditionally - as your curate.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Jane, I don't need a curate; I need a wife.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I must have my heart and mind free, my own self to turn to. I couldn't become part of you -

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: A part of me you must become or the whole bargain is void. How can I, a man not yet thirty take out to India a girl of nineteen, unless she is my wife? Don't offer God half a sacrifice. He must have all. And undoubtedly enough of love would follow to make the union right, even in your eyes.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Enough of love?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Yes, quite enough.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: St John, I scorn your idea of love. I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer and I scorn you when you offer it!

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I've uttered nothing that deserves scorn.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Forgive me but the very name of love is an apple of discord between us. My dear cousin, please abandon your scheme of marriage.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: No; and if you reject it, it's not me you deny but God.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Do not be angry with me please. It makes me wretched. I want us to be friends.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: We are friends. I hope we can be more.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I cannot come as your wife.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why this refusal? It makes no sense!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: If I were to marry you, you'd kill me. You're killing me now.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I'd kill you? I am killing you? Your words are violent, unfeminine and untrue -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You'd kill me without drawing any blood or receiving on your conscience any stain of crime.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: What nonsense is this?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You'd experience no pain - but I tell you it would kill me!

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Because I would inevitably come to conceive love for you, because you are so talented and good, because there is such grandeur in your look. You wouldn't want this strange and torturing love; if I showed it you would find it unbecoming. And my lot would be wretched.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Jane...

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: You're a good man, but you forget the feelings of little people. We'd better keep out of your way lest you trample us.

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: I wouldn't trample you. You'd walk at my side towards God's altar. He'd be your solace, heaven your reward. We seek to do the greatest work, to open death's gates, to save souls. Love God Jane, love God.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: If I were sure; if I were certain -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Oh God, what is it?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: What have you heard? What can you see?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I am coming!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Wait for me!

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: They sent me from the inn. I've been up at the house -

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Come in, come in.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Is he dead?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: No, no. Mr Rochester still lives.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Tell me - please -

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Why did you run away in the night like that? I would have helped. I would have helped.

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: He sought you as if you were a lost and precious jewel. He didn't rest. And as days turned into weeks and no word came, he grew quite savage in his disappointment.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: He stayed at Thornfield?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: Didn't leave the house...

Speaker: grace
Dialogue: Antoinetta?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: He's alive child, but many think he'd be better off dead.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: mrs fairfax
Dialogue: When he was taken out from under the ruins, a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him, partly - but his eye was taken out and his left hand so crushed that he lost it. The other eye inflamed and - he is blind. He's blind.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I had dreaded worse. I'd dreaded he was mad.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I can see the candles, Martha, at your side like a luminous glow. And the fire; a red haze.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Martha is in the kitchen, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Pilot knows me. Will you have some more water? I've spilt half the glass.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: If you are real, touch me.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: And her voice.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Jane Eyre - Jane Eyre.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: My Edward, I am Jane Eyre: I have found you out. I am come back to you.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're not lying dead in some ditch? Not an outcast among strangers?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I've been with good people; far better than you, quite more refined and exalted.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: She insults me -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: And I'm an independent woman. My uncle in Madeira died and left me five thousand pounds -

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: This is real. This is practical.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm here. I'm home. I am where I love best.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: You're altogether a human being, Jane?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I conscientiously believe so, sir.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: I'm a sightless block -

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: rochester
Dialogue: Am I hideous, Jane?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Very. But you always were, you know.
